Michael has nothing to do with this :-)

Why does StandardJavaElementContentProvider.getChildren() cause a Workspace operation (which is potentially long-running)?  As can be seen in the stack trace, this leads to a reentrant call into the same TreeViewer instance that called StandardJavaElementContentProvider.getChildren(), except this time, refresh() is called. This can alter the internal data structures, which in the worst case leads to NPEs later on (when the control returns to AbstractTreeViewer.isExpandable()) because the internal data structure of the TreeViewer may be corrupt now.

The JFace viewers are not designed to handle reentrant/recursive calls like this, but in the past never detected this situation, they just threw NPEs as they happened. ;-)

If JDT cannot fix their content provider for M7, I can remove the check for being busy in the viewers.  However, the problematic reentrant calls will still happen.

I looked at the stack trace again, and here is why it is correct that the viewer ignores the call to refresh() and writes to the log:

CommonNavigator.createPartControl() creates the tree viewer and initializes it. As part of that (probably the last step) it sets the input, upon which the viewer initializes the tree. It does that by getting the root elements and iterating over them, asking whether any of these elements have children so that it can show a plus sign for the expandable items. It is unsafe to let a refresh operation happen while the viewer is still iterating over the root elements, because the refresh could change the structure of the tree in unexpected ways.

I think it's ok that contentProvider.getChildren can do some of its work in a workspace runnable.
But its not good to have a resource listener that does refresh(). This needs to be posted with async exec. (there's long discussions about that in some bug)

But I wonder if there is really a resource change happening. Maybe just a marker change?

Back to Michael.

(In reply to comment #3)
> (there's long discussions about that in some bug)

Bug 75843.

Martin should remain in the loop.

See bug 154571 for more background about reentrant calls into viewers.

From bug 154571 I think it is ok to update in sync, if you are already in the display thread.
But it has to be investigated what exactly the resource delta is.
If it is resource add or remove, then this probably a bug in jdt.core.
Just to clarify, the refresh does run in an async(). There's a list of runnables aggregated that is executed in a Display.async() after the delta has been processed.

This is still assigned to me, but I do not believe there is much I can do here.

The exceptions are due to the fix for bug 154571, in ColumnViewer. ColumnViewer is new for 3.3, and the isBusy() method is new as of >20070426-0010. After talking with Boris, we concluded the best solution for 3.3 was to make the isBusy() method log the issue only once. Clients really shouldn't be causing re-entrant calls through the viewer, via async() or not, but many clients currently do. For 3.4, we will have to identify these, using the log message. 

Assigning back to Boris to carry out this fix. 

My concern with just identifying this specific issue in the JDT extension, while I think it should be corrected, I'm sure there are going to be downstream clients that will not be able to react in time for 3.3 (in CDT/WTP/adopters). Once the Platform moves into RC mode, it will be hard for these consumers to push for a fix in the platform layers. Particularly, I know for a fact that any downstream contributors of Java classpath containers will trigger workspace operations that can result in notifications back through to the viewer. WTP has this issue for J2EE Classpath Containers.
I have released changes to JFace so that only one exception is logged per viewer instance.

Note that the logging is just a side-effect here, and the underlying problem remains.  The remaining problem is either in the listener or the content provider.  I believe it's perfectly valid for a listener to modify the UI when it is called in the UI thread (there is no syncExec or asyncExec going on here). So, I suggest moving to JDT because they are triggering changes that modify the UI from within their content provider.  In the past this *might* have worked ok, but it's a problematic coding pattern that can cause NPEs or index out of bounds exceptions as the tree is modified as it is being populated.  It may not be necessary to fix this for 3.3 if it's too disruptive...

I tried to reproduce the problem to see what the resource delta contains, but I was unable to find a reproducible case.

Same here - I wasn't able to reproduce this.  Michael, I believe you have reproduced this at least once - do you have steps?

Assigning to JDT as per John's suggestion.

I found a similar exception in my log.
This shows that it doesn't even help to do a async exec, as the EventLoopProgressMonitor allows the UI events to be executed right away.

I'm not sure if this is new or the result of a performance fix that delayed the initialization of the classpath containers. It would be better to have no resource changes when evaluating the children. Philippe, can you give insights what resource chaanges are sent out here? Is the 'Project.touch' of the project really needed?

Boris -- I didn't have a reproducible case, but I have similar re-entrant behavior with a getChildren() causing multiple calls to viewer.update().

Martin, the stack trace you found is even scarier - content or label providers must not cause spinning the event loop.  Anything could happen, including disposing of the tree, completely changing it, etc...

Philippe, can you comment on the changes that are done in the classpath container initializer?
Getting the children of a project should not have any side effects on resources.
*** Bug 189143 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Created an attachment (id=69526)
patch

One bug is that the navigator does a 'getChildren' on 'hasChildren' and therefore accesses all children.

The patch fixes that.

Re: comment 15 (sorry didn't see the question up until now)
I think the #touch(...) comes from a classpath container change, which in turn is touching the project, so that an autobuild may get triggered as expected. This isn't new behavior, rather an unfortunate place for it to occur in your scenario (but how can we know?).

cc'ing Jerome who may be more helpful.
haven't seen this anymore in bug reports. Moving target to 3.4.

Created an attachment (id=79276)
Backtrace in Errorlog when starting 3.3.1 first time

I found a similar backtrace when starting 3.3.1 the first time on an existing larget workspace (WinXP SP1 / Sun 1.6.0_02). It rebuilt the entire workspace, then I found attached backtrace in the log.

Just to be clear, the message associated with the exception was:
"Ignored reentrant call while viewer is busy. This is only logged once per viewer instance, but similar calls will still be ignored."
*** Bug 207297 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I don't think we can prevent events from happening when we access the model. But we can delay the refreshes.

Boris, would it be possible to provide a protected access to the 'isBusy' flag?
(without logging?)

(In reply to comment #23)
> Boris, would it be possible to provide a protected access to the 'isBusy' flag?
> (without logging?)

Yes, but if possible I would prefer a solution without this. Would it work to delay all refreshes?

In the package explorer delaying the refreshes would work. We have a refresh queue   that we can delay or force to be processed.

Do you see an alternative way of solving this problem?

(In reply to comment #25)
> In the package explorer delaying the refreshes would work. We have a refresh
> queue   that we can delay or force to be processed.
> 
> Do you see an alternative way of solving this problem?

I am not sure I understand. My question in comment #24 was if it is possible to always delay refreshes, i.e. you would never force the queue to be processed.
*** Bug 208607 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Yes, in the package explorer we could always delay the UI refreshes while the viewer is busy.

That's what is happening in the stacktrace of comment 12:
a.) content provider is asked to get the children of a project
b.) the Java model is populating on request. Getting the children of a project the first time will initialize class path containers, what can result in a Java element deltas. If I understand right, this happens when the resulting roots are different to the roots seen previously (last workbench start). JDT core knows more.
c.) the delta is processed in the package explorer and all changes are kept in a change queue. An 'async-exec' runnable is posted to process the queue at a later moment.
d.) The EventLoopProgressMonitor serves the UI queue on calls like isCancelled and processes the async exec. Because of this, the change runnables are already processed, while getChildren has not yet finished.

With API access like 'isBusy', we can delay the processing of the update runnable when we detect that the async exec is called in busy time: we would just repost the async exec.

Some notes:
- I can rebuild the 'busy' flag in my tree viewer by overriding getRawChildren. But it would be easier to access the existing flag.
- Changing the Java model to not send out deltas while children are accessed would be, if possible at all, a complicated change that JDT core isn't planing to do.
- The situation shows a problem of using 'async-exec' to post something after a given action. The display loop is served at several unexpected places like the EventLoopProgressMonitor.
Implementing a 'post event after' is not really possible with async-exec, but I'm not aware of a better replacement. We have similar problems when posting UI events out of a build notification (resource or Java delta). 
- Other viewers don't post UI changes but refresh in sync. This would lead to the same problem here. I don't know what the solution would be with such viewers.

Thanks Martin.  You convinced me that making isBusy() available as API is important. The root of all evil seems to be that clients call refresh()/add()/remove() etc. directly instead of having a listener API available for the viewer. If the viewer was a listener that is notified of changes, it could choose to process the changes when appropriate.

I have filed bug 208916 for the API request.

fixed > 20071214

fixed as described in comment 28. UI updating is rescheduled when the viewer is still busy.
